content.text: Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1, with the mass resting on the bench
Adjust the height of the boss and the position of the mass until the wooden strip is parallel to the bench and the springs are vertical
Measure and record the lengths \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) of the coiled sections of the two springs, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Hang the hook and about half the rings from string loop Y
Repeat (a)(ii) and (a)(iii)
Using the data from the card, calculate the total mass \(m\) hanging from string loop Y
You are provided with a wire hook and some metal rings. The card shows the mass of the hook and the mass of one ring
Change \(m\) by altering the number of rings on the hook, and repeat **(a)(ii)**, **(a)(iii)** and **(b)(iii)** until you have six sets of values of \(m\), \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\)
Record your results in a table
Include values of \((l_{2} - l_{1})\) in your table
Plot a graph of \((l_{2} - l_{1})\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(m\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =

where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants
Use your answers from **(d)(iii)** to determine the values of \(a\) and \(b\)
Give appropriate units

where \(g = 9.81 \text{N} \text{kg}^{-1}\)
Calculate \(k\)
In this experiment, you will investigate forces on a wooden strip in equilibrium
Select the pipe with the **larger** diameter
The outside diameter of the pipe is \(D\), as shown in Fig. 2.1
Take measurements to find \(D\)
Record \(D\)
Write down the mass \(m\) of the newton-meter as written on the card
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the newton-meter using the expression
where \(g = 9.81 \text{N} \text{kg}^{-1}\)
Justify the number of significant figures you have given for your value of \(W\)

Use the stand, boss and clamp to hold the pipe securely parallel to the bench. Adjust the height of the boss until the pipe is approximately \(50 \text{cm}\) above the bench. Assemble the rest of the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2, with the string passing over the pipe
Slowly pull down the hook of the newton-meter so that the mass is lifted off the bench and continues to rise
As the mass is rising steadily, record the reading \(F\) from the newton-meter
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(F\)
Repeat (a)(ii) and (c) using the **smaller** diameter plastic pipe
It is suggested that the relationship between \(F, W\) and \(D\) is
where \(k\) is a constant
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)
first value of \(k =\)
second value of \(k =\)
Explain whether your results in **(f)**(i) support the suggested relationship
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**
In this experiment, you will investigate the friction between string and a plastic pipe
